The answers here so far leave quite a bit to be desired. Glyn Williams's answer is the best so far, but it leaves a lot out. Make sure you read his answer; I won't reiterate what he said.  Most computers on the market today are designed to be inexpensive. They use cheap, mass-market components to minimize cost. The result is a computer that isn't particularly great for people who demand a lot of their computer.  The Mac Pro eschews these norms. It's made of only the best, highest quality, and generally most expensive components. Some of these components add fault tolerance features so that if something goes wrong at a very low level (which would cause a normal computer to crash), they can detect the problem and compensate for it (so that the computer can keep working).  It is incredibly fast and powerful. Most computers this powerful are servers; designed to sit in a server room in a big rack of similar servers. They have loud fans and lots of blinking lights. They are designed with entirely different purposes in mind. People who work with images and video for a living (among other less obvious professions, like software developers) need a very powerful, very reliable computer to get their job done efficiently. Before the Mac Pro, the computer whose capabilities matched their needs wasn't designed with them in mind. Nobody in their right mind would use one of those rack-mount server computers on their desk to edit video, and so these professionals would generally compromise and instead buy a high-end desktop computer. The Mac Pro is designed to better fulfill the needs of these professionals. It is compact and quiet. It's capable of driving six monitors at once.  It's monstrously fast.
